try.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to take action in order to do something that you may not be able to do
try.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: Let’s have a rest and then we’ll try again.
I tried everything to lose weight with no success.
I tried and tried (=kept making an effort) and eventually I was offered a job.
Try as he might (=as hard as he could), he could not get the incident out of his mind.
She dabbed at her face and tried hard not to sniff.
I tried my best to comfort her.
They didn’t get any goals, but it wasn’t for lack of trying.
it wasn’t for lack/want of trying
She couldn’t speak French if she tried.
you couldn’t do something if you tried
He tried to control his voice.
She was trying not to cry.
Try and take some form of daily exercise.
try.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to do or use something for a short while to discover if it is suitable, successful, enjoyable etc
try.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: It works really well – you should try it.
If I’m going out for a meal, I prefer to try something different.
Always try a sleeping bag for size before you buy it.
They decided they would try living in America for a while.
Try logging off and logging on again.
We tried the machine on hardwood and soft wood.
Petra’s trying the baby on solid foods.
try.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to taste food or drink to find out if you like it
try.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Would you like to try some crisps?
try.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to go to a place or person, or call them, in order to find something or someone
try.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Sorry, he’s not in. Would you like to try again later?
Let’s try Mouncy Street. He could be there.
try.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to attempt to open a door, window etc in order to see if it is locked
try.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: She tried the door and it opened.
He tried the handle but the door was locked.
try.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to examine and judge a legal case, or someone who is thought to be guilty of a crime in a court
try.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: The defence argued that a regional court was not competent to try their case.
He was tried for attempting to murder his wife.
try.translation[0].definitions[5].note_b: Try is often passive in this meaning
try.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: She was trying hard not to show her impatience.
They try desperately to please other people.
He has tried unsuccessfully to quit smoking.
Try your best to block out other distractions.
If you try to do something, you attempt to do it
We must try to prevent this from happening again
If you try doing something, you do it in order to find out if it is enjoyable or produces the result you want
Try using margarine instead of butter
try.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: try
to take action in order to do something that you may not be able to do
I tried to explain what was wrong.
He tries hard in class, but he’s finding the work difficult.
attempt
to try to do something, especially something difficult. Attempt is more formal than try  and is used especially in written English
Any prisoner who attempts to escape will be shot.
He was attempting to climb one of the world’s highest mountains.
do your best
to try as hard as you can to do something
We will do our best to help them.
make an effort to do something
to try to do something, when you find this difficult
It is worth making an effort to master these skills.
She made a big effort to be nice to him.
struggle
to try very hard to do something that is very difficult, especially for a long time
She’s still struggling to give up smoking.
Many of these families are struggling to survive.
strive
to try very hard to achieve something
The company must constantly strive for greater efficiency.
endeavour
to try hard to do something
Each employee shall endeavour to provide customers with the best service possible.
have a go/try
to try to do something, especially when you are not sure that you will succeed
I’m not very good at fixing taps, but I’ll have a go.
Do you want to have another try?
see if you can do something
to try to do something – used when offering to do something, or suggesting that someone should do something
I’ll see if I can get you a ticket.
See if you can persuade her to come.
try.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: She didn’t manage to break the record, but it was a good try.
‘You really think you can do that?’ ‘I’m going to have a try.’
‘What are the chances for getting tickets now?’ ‘I guess I could give it a try.’
It might sound a ludicrous excuse but he thought it was worth a try.
Only half the students passed the test on their first try.
try.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: a test of something to see if it is suitable or successful or to find out if you like it
try.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: I decided to give modelling a try.
Wines from Apulia’s ancient vineyards are well worth a try.
try.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: four points won by putting the ball on the ground behind the opponents’ goal line in  rugby
try.translation[1].note_box[0].sections[: I decided to have one last try.
If your instinct is telling you to give it a try, then go ahead.
It’s worth a try – we’ve nothing to lose.
‘Do you really think you can win?’ ‘I’m going to have a darn good try.’
Nice try, Claudia, but not good enough, I’m afraid.
This is his first try at directing.
try.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to examine and judge a legal case, or someone who is thought to be guilty of a crime in a court
try.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: Savings-and-loan directors are being tried for fraud.
